sets.setTitle: Set 1: Defining Relative Clauses (Who, Which, That)

examples.before: The man lives next door. He is a doctor.
examples.after: The man <<who>> lives next door is a doctor.

examples.before: The book is on the table. It belongs to me.
examples.after: The book <<which/that>> is on the table belongs to me.

examples.before: I met a woman. She works at the hospital.
examples.after: I met a woman <<who>> works at the hospital.

examples.before: The car was expensive. I bought it yesterday.
examples.after: The car <<which/that>> I bought yesterday was expensive.

examples.before: People live in glass houses. They shouldn't throw stones.
examples.after: People <<who>> live in glass houses shouldn't throw stones.

examples.before: The woman is a teacher. Her daughter won the prize.
examples.after: The woman <<whose>> daughter won the prize is a teacher.

examples.before: I know a man. His brother is famous.
examples.after: I know a man <<whose>> brother is famous.

examples.before: That's the house. Its roof is red.
examples.after: That's the house <<whose>> roof is red.

examples.before: She married a man. His family is very wealthy.
examples.after: She married a man <<whose>> family is very wealthy.

examples.before: The company went bankrupt. Its CEO resigned.
examples.after: The company <<whose>> CEO resigned went bankrupt.

examples.before: That's the restaurant. We had our first date there.
examples.after: That's the restaurant <<where>> we had our first date.

examples.before: Do you remember the day? We first met then.
examples.after: Do you remember the day <<when>> we first met?

examples.before: This is the town. I was born here.
examples.after: This is the town <<where>> I was born.

examples.before: I'll never forget the moment. I heard the news then.
examples.after: I'll never forget the moment <<when>> I heard the news.

examples.before: The hotel is very comfortable. We stayed there last year.
examples.after: The hotel <<where>> we stayed last year is very comfortable.

examples.before: My brother lives in London. He is a lawyer.
examples.after: My brother, <<who>> is a lawyer, lives in London.

examples.before: Paris is the capital of France. I visited it last year.
examples.after: Paris, <<which>> I visited last year, is the capital of France.

examples.before: My father is 65. He has just retired.
examples.after: My father, <<who>> is 65, has just retired.

examples.before: The Eiffel Tower is in Paris. It was built in 1889.
examples.after: The Eiffel Tower, <<which>> was built in 1889, is in Paris.

examples.before: Emma Thompson is a famous actress. I met her yesterday.
examples.after: Emma Thompson, <<whom>> I met yesterday, is a famous actress.

sets.setTitle: Set 1: Obligation & Advice (Must, Should, Ought To)

examples.before: It's necessary for you to wear a helmet.
I advise you to see a doctor.
It's important to be on time.
It's compulsory to have insurance.
I recommend studying every day.

sets.setTitle: Set 2: Prohibition & No Necessity (Mustn't, Don't Have To)

examples.before: It's forbidden to smoke here.
It's not necessary to bring food.
Parking is not allowed here.
It's optional to wear a tie.
examples.after: You <<don't have to>> wear a tie.

examples.before: Entry is prohibited without a ticket.
She is able to speak five languages.
Is it okay if I use your phone?
He was able to swim when he was five.
examples.after: He <<could>> swim when he was five.

examples.before: Perhaps I'll come to the party.
Is it possible for me to leave early?
I'm sure she's at home. Her car is outside.
I'm certain he's not American. His accent is British.
It's possible that they're lost.
I'm sure this is the right answer.
It's impossible that she's 50. She looks 30.
I think he's coming.
examples.after: I <<don't think>> he's coming. (NOT: I think he's not coming.)

examples.before: I believe she likes it.
She has some money.
They saw someone.
I suppose you're right.
There aren't any people here.
I don't have any friends in London.
Not one of them passed the exam.
I don't like coffee. I don't like tea either.
She doesn't speak French. She doesn't speak German either.

sets.setTitle: Set 3: Negative Adverbs (Never, Hardly, Barely, Scarcely)

examples.before: I don't ever want to see him again.
examples.after: I <<never>> want to see him again.

examples.before: I almost didn't pass the exam.
We had almost no time to finish.
She almost never goes out.
I've not been there even once.
You like pizza, right?
Don't you think it's expensive?
She isn't coming, right?
You haven't seen him, right?
Isn't she beautiful?
John broke the window.
examples.after: <<It was John who>> broke the window.

examples.before: I need a holiday.
She met him in Paris.
examples.after: <<It was in Paris that>> she met him.

examples.before: They fired him because he was lazy.
examples.after: <<It was because he was lazy that>> they fired him.

examples.before: The noise woke me up.
examples.after: <<It was the noise that>> woke me up.

examples.before: I need some rest.
She said something very rude.
You should apologize.
He wants more money.
They did something terrible.

sets.setTitle: Set 3: The Thing That / The Person Who

examples.before: His attitude annoys me.
examples.after: <<The thing that>> annoys me is his attitude.

examples.before: Mary told me the news.
examples.after: <<The person who>> told me was Mary.

examples.before: I hate waiting in queues.
examples.after: <<The thing I hate>> is waiting in queues.

examples.before: His brother gave him the money.
examples.after: <<The person who>> gave him the money was his brother.

examples.before: The weather ruined our holiday.
examples.after: <<The thing that>> ruined our holiday was the weather.

examples.before: I only want the truth.
He just needs some encouragement.
We did nothing but watch TV.
She only said 'hello'.
I only asked a simple question.
examples.after: <<All I asked>> was a simple question.

examples.before: There's no doubt that he's guilty.
Obviously, safety is important.
examples.after: <<It goes without saying that>> safety is important.

examples.before: I'm not surprised you're tired.
Concerning the price, we can negotiate.
examples.after: <<With regard to>> the price, we can negotiate.

examples.before: And the situation became even worse.
examples.after: And <<to make matters worse>>, the situation became even worse.

sets.setTitle: Set 2: In Terms Of / As Far As

examples.before: Regarding quality, this product is excellent.
examples.after: <<In terms of>> quality, this product is excellent.

examples.before: Concerning money, I'm doing fine.
examples.after: <<As far as>> money is concerned, I'm doing fine.

examples.before: About the location, it's perfect.
When we talk about experience, he's the best.
examples.after: <<In terms of>> experience, he's the best.

examples.before: Regarding my opinion, I disagree.
examples.after: <<As far as>> I'm concerned, I disagree.

examples.before: I considered all the options.
examples.after: I <<took into account>> all the options.

examples.before: Don't assume I'll help you.
examples.after: Don't <<take it for granted that>> I'll help you.

examples.before: Let's assume she's telling the truth.
examples.after: Let's <<take it for granted that>> she's telling the truth.

examples.before: This car uses a lot of petrol.
examples.after: This car <<makes use of>> a lot of petrol.

examples.before: Everyone noticed his absence.
Finally, we decided to leave.
examples.after: <<In the end>>, we decided to leave.

examples.before: Eventually, everything worked out.
examples.after: <<In the long run>>, everything worked out.

examples.before: Generally speaking, I prefer coffee.
After all our efforts, we failed.
examples.after: Despite all our efforts, we failed <<in the end>>.

examples.before: Under no circumstances should you lie.
There isn't a lot of time.
There aren't a lot of people here.
We have a small amount of money.
There are not many students absent.
He doesn't have a lot of patience.

sets.setTitle: Set 2: A Few / A Little (Positive) vs. Few / Little (Negative)

examples.before: We have some time. (positive)
There are some people here. (positive)
We have almost no time. (negative)
Almost nobody came. (negative)
I have some money, so I can help.
examples.after: I have <<a little>> money, so I can help.

examples.before: Every student passed the exam.
All students must wear uniform.
Every single person received a gift.
Everything was ready.
I see him every day.
The two options are good.
Not one of the two answers is correct.
You can choose one or the other.
Tom and Jerry are absent.
I don't like this one. I don't like that one.
examples.after: I like <<neither>> this one <<nor>> that one.

examples.before: I have a little money.
Do you have any questions?
There aren't any problems.
Would you like a little water?
I don't have any idea.
